content.body: Q: Are `SyntaxError`'s reserved only for early errors / parsing errors, or can it be thrown by APIs?
content.formatted_body: Q: Are SyntaxError's reserved only for early errors / parsing errors, or can it be thrown by APIs?

content.body: They can be thrown by APIs; JSON.parse throws SyntaxErrors for invalid input.
content.formatted_body: They can be thrown by APIs; JSON.parse throws SyntaxErrors for invalid input.

content.body: * They can be thrown by APIs; JSON.parse and parseInt throw SyntaxErrors for invalid input.
content.formatted_body: * They can be thrown by APIs; JSON.parse and parseInt throw SyntaxErrors for invalid input.

m.new_content.body: They can be thrown by APIs; JSON.parse and parseInt throw SyntaxErrors for invalid input.
m.new_content.formatted_body: They can be thrown by APIs; JSON.parse and parseInt throw SyntaxErrors for invalid input.

content.body: (parseInt should throw SyntaxError, but it returns NaN instead. https://github.com/tc39/proposal-number-fromstring would throw SyntaxErrors.)
* (parseInt should throw SyntaxError, but it returns NaN instead. https://github.com/tc39/proposal-number-fromstring would throw SyntaxErrors.)

m.new_content.body: (parseInt should throw SyntaxError, but it returns NaN instead. https://github.com/tc39/proposal-number-fromstring would throw SyntaxErrors.)

content.body: Does this seem like the right intuition?
i would prefer a syntax error, since the syntax is wrong. but i think something in the web recently chose type error for something like that with URLs
